column3: I was just back for the second time and this is still my favorite city in Latin America. Climate, friendliness, architecture, food, activities ... this city has it all.

The city is very impressive. Big, surrounded by the mountains and with the hundreds and hundreds of houses all around them. At night, it looks gorgeous. Medellin comes to life everyday with its busy inhabitants or its crazy nightlife filled with music, dances, restaurants and bars.

We stayed in La Poblado which is a very nice area in Medellin. We did a lot of reading on Medellin and were careful. We had no issues on our three day visit. Don't know if that was our carefulness or just luck. Here's what we learned and did. We did not walk much, we took cabs which are very inexpensive. Our Colombian friends flagged cabs on the street (which you are not supposed to do).The sketchy areas are downtown. That is where the sculpture park is. We went Sunday morning which was a good choice. I would never go there alone or at night.I would say that speaking Spanish is a must. We had Colombian friends. If we didn't have them, I would have booked a local guide. In many places you can get buy with just English, this isn't one of them.I would not dissuade someone from going to Medellin, just be careful. And, don't wear jewelry or dress in a way that makes you look wealthy.The weather was incredible, warm and dry. Apparently it is like that all the time.

We really enjoyed a day trip to Guatape and El Penon - would recommend hiring a private taxi to do this, We hired Govany 573003272855 (also on Whats app) and he was very accommodating. We also used him for our airport transfers. But be warned that you need to establish ahead of time what size vehicle you are ordering and the cost. A lot of the taxis are too small for 4 people and suitcases - fortunately we only had carry on and were able to make do with the smaller vehicle because the larger vehicle doubled the cost of the transfer.We felt very safe during the daytime and used a taxi driver we knew for when we wanted to go anywhere at night.We used the Hop on Hop off for seeing the city - great way to go but unfortunately when you do get someone who speaks English on the HoHo it isn't great because they don't offer headsets.We were very impressed with the courtesy of the Colombian people, the skill of the drivers on the road and the cleanliness of the city.

Medellin has really been trying to change its image and you can feel it in the people, the metro, the roads and everything else the city is trying to do.The nightlife, the cable cars, parque arvi and the cleaned up slums, you have to visit!

Medellin is super beautiful and stunning for anyone who is not used to seeing what seems to be a landscape of infinite mountains. I love the genuine paisan nature of the people - caring. At least, that is what I have experienced.If you want to have a great time, to experience the real Medellín, go with Guanabana Tours. Ask for Juan

Ofcourse Medellín had it's nice sites, the cable carts the views, cheap para gliding, shopping near the metropolitana cathedral, but it is really just another big and dirty city. If you are traveling to colombia pick either Bogota or Medellín (both is over doing the big city thing)Make sure to pick a hotel NOT situated in Maturín (a neighbourhood naar the city centre) it is said to nooit be save at night and taxi's won't go there. They will have some excuse as to not knowing that part of town or they have to drive a long way in the wrong direction to get there (please get out and get a cab at the other side of the street. -the cab on the other side will tell you the same-)

We only went for 3 days because the flights were cheap...we could have stayed for more.Absolutely beautiful! Fresh, clean, green, spring time climate, gorgeous mountains, brilliant flowers, friendly people, delicious food, inexpensive...shall I go on?There were areas of the city that were filthy with homelessness and drugs. Just beware of that. It was such a contrast to most of what we saw.The metro may be great but involves a LOT of stair climbing and walking to locations. Taxis are cheap and tours are cheap, so use them. There is a tour that is a city bus tour where you can get off and on and it's only @ $16.00 USD for all day.A trip to Guatape on Tour Guatape (best deal ever) is highly recommended.Enjoy the fresh mountain air, and the somehow amazing beauty of this place, even though there are 4 million people.

Medellin is definitely my favourite place in South America. Surprisingly safe, modern and developed, the city is full of amazing bars and restaurants of a high quality but everything is still really cheap! I stayed at happy Buddha hostel in El Poblado which was so much fun but then moved to hotel acqua just down the road after a few nights which was perfect for a relaxing night! The local people were amazing and so welcoming and the atmosphere is just unbelievable! Will definitely go back one day!!

column2: “One of the best cities in the world ”
column3: This is One of the best cities in the world you have to visit it is beautiful, clean, modern, shopping malls are world class, people are friendly, also is safe is not like used to be on the 80s -90s. My family and I we always look to go to medellin as a top choice, that's why it was name the world's most Innovative city.

It's Medellin. One of the most innovative cities in the world. Trust me, it surprised me too. But the beauty of the city lies with its culture, it's history, it's good and it's views and the people have a lot to do with it as well. They are super nice and the times of gangsters and kidnappings are a thing of the past, per my experience. Its still South America and you still have to be careful but people here don't mind helping you out with a smile and making sure you have a great time in their city.

column2: “Perfect climate, great value and a beautiful city...”
column3: Spent 6 days in Medellìn this December. I was surprised at how beautiful the city is. Very green, trees everywhere...lots of shade. The climate is perfect year-round. Because of the strong dollar everything is reasonable priced. Overall, I found the people to be polite and friendly. Taxi's are cheap and I never had to fight with them like in so many cities around the world. In December the Christmas lights around town are awesome...do the Christmas lights tour from Pablado park. Ride the Metro and Metro cable into the favelas. Highly recommend!

column2: “A perfect retirement city for expats and Colombians”
column3: Perfect climate - no heating, no air conditioning, no screens needed. Low of cost of living. A city IN the green, green Northern Andes. (As opposed to a city NEXt TO mountains such as Seattle, Denver, LA. Anchorage.) No need for a car; taxis inexpensive. (traffic awful). The kindest people. Excellent, state of the art healthcare facilities. We visited from beautiful Alaska in February, a rental apartment "fell into our lap" through friends of friends. We now live in Laureles in a neighborhood of high rise apartments with local shops on many first floors - just what urban planners are trying to get back to in the U S. We did not know Spanish and only the younger people here have studied English, but we all manage to communicate somehow. We had researched Mexico, Central and other South American countries and at age 70 feel we have found the Perfect Place in Medellin!
Lovely city, people are extremely friendly, love this place, will always come backI strongly recommend to come here in December

Medellin is a really cool city. Crammed with red houses and high rises on every nook and cranny of the valley between two mountain ranges. El Poblado is the place to stay for sure. It's safe and packed full of nice hotels and restaurants (and women's shoes and purse stores). So we ate until nearly sick at many of the great eats. Lots of vegetarian and international options if you're a little tired of beans rice and plantains.

The mountains, valleys and climate are just three of the things that make this a beautiful city. There is so much to see in the way of history and lots of great sights to visit. We were there for 4 1/2 days, and that felt like the least amount of time needed to get a good feel of Medellin. The paisas (Medellin locals) are proud and hard working people, who are helpful and friendly. At a minimum, make sure to go on "The Real City Walking Tour", visit "the rock" in Guatape, ride the Medellin metro, take the Metro cable, enjoy Parque Lleras and snack at the hundreds of fruit and coffee stands. We found the prices in Medellin to be extremely reasonable - Enjoy. You will be glad you did!

"colombia's best city" is also colombia's most over-rated. If you've seen Bogotá, cali, and barranquilla it's much easier to understand how low the bar is set.With no historical center to speak of and virtually no attractive architecture, medellín's main offer is a strange neighborhood that is part european bistro village, part mtv spring break in cancun. Come and be baffled by it all. Oh, and they have a metro! Just in case you hadn't heard five thousand times from every local you talk to. Apparently installing basic public transportation is all it takes for a developing country to win awards. By all means get on that metro (there are 1.5 lines so you're totally spoiled for options). When you get off you'll be greeted by offers of cocaine in case you forgot to pick some up at your hostel.+weather+scenery/parks+the people are friendly and attractive+teleferico-drugs-more drugs-yet more drugs-bland as hell-plastic people talking about how wonderful they and their city are

Many things have been said about this city, but you have go and see for yourself. It is amazing to see their structure,the beauty of the mountains, lakes, and so much they have to offer. Many places to see. The bike tours are incredible, Parque years has all the nightlife you need, malls are amazing. Food is great and you do all this for a minimum price per the dollar rate exchange is at best now.

Medellín is a quite nice city but in my opinion completely different to Bogotá. Louder, more crowded and more stressful. Barrio El Poblado is a lovely place with nice bars and restaurants and a good barrio to stay. It's safe and central.
Here is most of the sculture of Fernando botero, museums food, the plaza bolívar the metro station just be a little careful to many homeless

This is the place to be! So incredulously cheap. So clean, nice, safe, easy to get around. Beautiful mountains, flowers, transit system, parks, and museums. There is great food as well. Medellin cuisine is unique within Columbia. Arepas, tamales, etc are different but excellent. As the Botero painting shows Pablo is dead (and has been for more than 20 years). It may surprise you but this is not an upcoming place. Medellin has arrived, take advantage before it becomes a tourist trap.
Medellin is a great urban city surrounded by nature. At no time did I feel unsafe while exploring the city. The local people were extreamly friendly and helpful.

We spent a glorious week in Medellin, the city of life. This is a vibrant city that works. People are very proud of what they’ve accomplished. We stayed at Hotel Poblado Plaza. It’s centrally located with nice rooms, friendly and helpful staff, with a buffet breakfast included.We got 2 day tickets to Turibus. It’s a hop on hop off bus that allows you to stay as long as you want at stops and then get the next bus. At some stops, we stayed and hour and other more than 2 hours. You get to see so much on this tour. Some of the stops we spent time at were: Parque Explora, Parque Botanico, Cerro Nutibara, Parque de los descalzados, Parque Botero, Museo de Antioquia, Centro Cultural Uribe Uribe, Junin St – a long pedestrian street in Centro. Tip: While the tourists are walking along this street, look for the places where there are lanes with stores perpendicular to the street. We went down one and it was a huge indoor complex of stores with a food court. This is where locals shop.El Poblado has the castle. Take the tour and stop to have a drink in the lovely garden. They offer picnics; and when we were there, there was an adult and a child’s birthday picnic party. There are 2 malls in El Poblado, each with a food court, supermarket and a movie theater. We had a frig in our room and got bottled water, fruit and snacks from the supermarkets. Santa Fe Mall has 5 floors and is sleek and modern. Oveido Mall has a Colombian flavor that we loved.The trip to Arvi Park is so special. We saw tour buses let people out at the park and they missed the best part - going on the metro and then on the metro cable.Tip: I printed out the metro map and a map of Centro before we left. IT helped to get your bearings. This is especially important if you don’t speak Spanish.Take a tour outside the city. We went with Tours Guatape and had a great guide, Angie. You’ll see colonial towns. My favorite was Guatape. You go to El Penol and have the option of going to the stores and restaurants or climbing the rock – 740 steps. We shopped. We took a boat ride and breakfast and lunch was included. Wonderful Day!!While tourists know about the drug wars, many don’t realize how or why the city has been transforming itself over the past 20 years. In You Tube videos you’ll learn a set of core values that have been put into action. These include a humane, more just city that’s inclusionary, more equitable, with a transparent government, and a commitment to education, with the building of schools next to parks and libraries, infrastructure that’s fast and efficient. When you’re on the metro cable you’ll see low income neighborhoods. They have water, electricity, paved streets, streetlights, schools and medical facilities.Public art is encouraged with statues and murals throughout the city. Community centers have been built throughout communities. They are very proud of their universities and have one of the best health care systems in Latin America. Come and see why Medellin was named the most innovative city in the world out of 200 world cities. We hope you enjoy Medellin as much as we did.

I was able to spend time in Colombia for the first time, and Medellin was absolutely an amazing city. I only spent a few days there, but here's what I was able to fit in: exploring Poblado, Guatape day tour (with tours guatape), cable car ride up to Arví to be out in nature hiking, a Nacional match at the stadium and a Pablo Escobar tour (with Paisa Road). I stayed in Poblado, which was a beautiful part of the city. Great restaurants, bars and shopping. A little more of a younger crowd, and definitely gets busy on weeknights. Public transportation (the metro) is very accessible and easy to use (much more so than Bogotá). It's easy to hop on and check out different parts of the city. I've heard Medellin is one of the most livable cities in South America and it lived up to that. If you have a few days or more in Colombia, Medellin is worth a visit.

I was there with my friends for the "Festival de las Flores". The city is beautiful with a clean and modern architecture. Night life is crazy, lots of people having fun and tons of rumba. I also felt secure, a couple of times went out for running some miles on the street and ended up doing some bars at the park. This happened around 11pm.

column2: “forget the reputation and go see for yourself”
column3: Medellin is synonymous with drugs wars and danger - no more. The death of drug kingpin Pablo Escobar celebrated in a painting by the city's famous artist Fernando Botero Angulo opened a brand new era. The modern city is exciting and safe with culture, food, and history. The exchange rate makes most things a bargain for overseas travelers which the fledgling tourist industry welcomes with open arms. Give it a try - I did and loved it.

What can I say? This city is rich in many aspects. There is nightlife everywhere. Visitors will always find cool things to do. Nice food, music and beautiful landscapes in the nearby zones. The city has nice squares, old churches, museums and teathers. People is very welcoming and the old stigmata from the town's past is almost gone.

column2: “A city wher you can find everything”
column3: A safe city, especially in Poblado, but be careful in the center and other areas.The police is corrupted, never argue with them, never carry drugs with you.
One of the beautiful cities ive even been, definitely recomended, just go and have fun all over the place

My family of four visited Medellin June 25 through June 28 and again July 8 through July 11th. The trip from the International airport cost $60,000 COP. We stayed at the Hotel San Fernando Plaza in Poblado, which was excellent! Our visit coincided with Copa America; Colombians are incredibly passionate about futball! We enjoyed visiting Parque Explora; riding the Metrocable and shopping at Santa Fe as well as picking up nice bargains in El Hueco. Look forward to returning to Medellin soon!

Awesome city, so much history (good and bad). Meca for interesting tours and activities, mixed with friendly people and excellent climate. City feels very safe and has a massive nightlife. Should be on the 'wish list' for travelers to south America.

Visited two cities in Colombia. Bogota, then Medellin. Medellin hands down!Dynamic City, Lots to see and do. Congested yes, but it works, Metro is a great way to go North or South within the City, easy to ride, modern, cheap , SAFE! Great way to see the people of Medellin. Great Modern City, Wonderful Clubs and Restaurants.Stayed in the Poblado District, nice!
This is one of the most amazing cities to go to. In Medellin you don't feel like a tourist. Everyone is nice and helpful you don't even need to go to ant attractions in this city to have a good time.

First time visit to Medellin, expecting to see all kinds of different things, found myself in a city that is astoundingly clean, despite how many people are there. I don't know if it was me, or who I was with, but I saw people of all kinds doing their job, and not once felt unsafe. I give Medellin a personal award for making so much progress, and making it with a will to forget their troubled past.Medellin es una ciudad que debe sentirse orgullosa por sus recientes logros, y su gente amable. Parte de Antioquia, la mas educada, es un simbolo que deben llevar bien en alto y representar la ciudad de la manera mas digna.

column2: “the city with the most delicious empanadas!”
column3: We visited Medellin after Guatape, look what we got?We found the best Empanadas ever in Colombia at this city. I love the Vibe at this city, remind me about Bandung, one of the city in Indonesia. its quite similar. 3 nights in Medellin made me happy!

column2: “Medellin: not what it used to be.”
column3: The name Medellin may bring to mind images of a city troubled by dangerous drug cartels and street shoot-outs. On the contrary, I have found a buzzing, modern city in which its two and a half million citizens go about with tremendous energy trying to make a living. The dangers are more in the way in which traffic is handled; there are three things in tremendous abundance in Medellin: thousands of motorbikes coming at you from every angle in fearless fashion, thousands of small yellow vehicles (taxis) and thousands of outrageously curvaceous girls which move in a desconcerting fashion. If you can watch out for these three potential dangers you'd be ok. If you're going to cross the road do not imagine for a minute that zebra crossings will afford you any safety. The city is clean and the people are helpful and kind. The area of Los Laureles on 70 is particularly lively specially at week ends and a half bottle of Medellin Rum and sodas on one of the terraces will only cost you about 25 dollars. Gastronomically I would not rate this area of Colombia very highly and apart from the the abundance of food in the dishes I did not find anything very exciting, although the quality of meat, specially beef, which is normally grilled, is very good. Be prepared to be served "arepas" (a thick corn tortilla) with everything. A good breakfast of eggs, cheese, arepa and cofee will set you back just over 3 dollars. A visit to the Pueblito Paisa will afford you great views of the city and a couple of hours in the Jardin Botanico will take you away from the hussle. Medellin: "I will be back!"

I recently visited Medellin and confirmed more than it was said to me: Beautiful clean safe progressive city surrounded by nature, order, among the most educated yet welcoming people in general, felt like home, willing to come back..

My first time in Colombia was during the troubled times of the 1990's. The country was in turmoil with a civil war raging and and the infamous Cartels engaged in a reign of terror with Medellin being especially dangerous. Even then however the people were extremely friendly and helpful to me and in spite of being a world traveler with many options I found myself drawn back to Colombia for vacations due to the variety of beautiful locations from beaches to the picturesque coffee country in the mountains. Under the leadership President Uribe and the current President Santos the civil war is about at an end and Colombia and Medellin has been transformed into a modern safe bustling place. After living here in Medellin for three years in what must be the world's most pleasant climate I continue to be amazed first and foremost by the people of this city who have a genuine affection for the USA and treat all foreigners with respect and a smile. With Medellin as a headquarters you can visit the gorgeous country side see top entertainment at the Teatro Metropolitano shop at modern malls, enjoy varied restaurants and see a miraculous change in a city that has now won awards from the NY Times. Get ready for construction everywhere as you can't keep a stellar place like this a secret as much as I would like to keep it all for myself! Just kidding C'mon Down!

On Tuesday 13 we got the Medellin City Tour with Turibus in the Poblado Park at 9:00 AM. The schedule route was 1-Botero Park, in there is near the Cultural Center Palace Rafael Uribe Uribe (“Palacio de la Cultura Rafael Uribe Uribe”) and the Antioquia Museum and the Hotel Nutibara Conference Plaza. 2- Wishes Park (“Parque de los Deseos”), in there is near to the Botanical Garden, Explora-Aquarium and Planetarium Parks and the Antioquia University. 3-Stadium and Sports Complex 4-“Pies Descalzos” Park (that it was close since this was the maintenance day) 5-Pueblito Paisa, it is a very good “replicate” at the top of the Nutibara mountain, where we sat together to eat the “Bandeja Paisa” in Cacique Restaurant. 6- Santa Fe Mall 7-Returning to the Poblado Park. This was a very tiring tour that required physical resistance, but was an excellent alternative to know the city in the different stops of the Turibus.We enjoyed so much!!!
An overlooked city, well worth spending a couple of days here, finally some good food after traveling for 3 weeks in Ecuador. Lots of energy and pretty suave people.

This city is trying hard to move ahead from the reputation of the 80's and 90's and is on the right path. The metro is cheap ,easy to use and clean. The city at night is lovely and at Christmas is lit up.But the city is dirty, plazas with garbage overflowing, the river is full of garbage and poor homeless people. We wonder about social services for the poor as many sleep everywhere on the sidewalks.Saying that, the city is worth a visit as it is evolving.

They have these great lights from end of November to Mid January. It was breathtaking, and visiting the surrounding towns was an extra bonus. We had no trouble at all, we did not rent a car, traffic is quite busy. We used the tour buses "Turibus" which took us everywhere in town and outside towns. Public transportation was always available. Try the local food is just awesome, and specially on the little towns, you NEVER had food this fresh. They have other festivals and everyone was talking about the Flower Festival in August. We were really amazed by the festival of lights!

This awesome city can give you soooo much, you may want to stay!!! It has the friendliest people, awesome food and great attractions. During Christmas, it has the "alumbrados" which are all around the city and down the river that you won't find in any other city around the world. Simply breath taking.
Great city, excellent food, good comerce. Airport is a little far away but good public transportation.
Medellin is an awesome city. especially the poblado has a lot to offer. Good nightlife good restaurants. and a beautiful coffee region very close.

Come visit Medellin and you will be pleasantly surprised!The city is located in a valley, so the views from the mtns are gorgeous. It's clean, the people are nice and the weather fantastic.Do NOT mix this up with the city that was once a hub for the drug lords - that is absolutely no longer. Of course like all places, it has it's crime, but the state and city government have worked very hard to make it a beautiful place to visit and one where it's inhabitants have pride which is very evident.Do you bike? There are many fantastic biking routes as Medellin is the centre of the Colombian biking world. Countless bikers are seen daily climbing the mtns, where a former Tour de France winner use to train.There are three large and quite fantastic shopping malls, of which my favorite and the most upscale, is El Tesoro with a children's mini amusement park.There is a wonderful aquarium that is deemed the largest in Latin America so the city is also a big attraction for families.If your visit calls for Colombia, ensure Medellin is a stop!

I don't know what I expected, but not a modern city in a beautiful location and certainly not a city with the most innovative social programs I've seen any place else in the world. Imagine--a cable car system to the formerly worst neighborhood in the city that links to the city rail and bus system, allowing it's people to get to work in a hour or less as opposed to the previous time of 3-4 hours--each way! Breakfast and lunch for school children so they absolutely go to school. and after school enrichment programs so they aren't out on the streets. and beautiful scenery to boot!
The Christmas light displays (El Alumbrado) are amazing! I mean amazing!!! The city itself is sophisticated and friendly. I am so pleasantly surprised!

column2: “Surprised what a great city Medellin is.”
column3: We stayed in Poblado district (hope I spelled that right). The choices of restaurants is great. The streets remind me of a European city - sidewalks, tree-lined, curvy. We were very comfortable walking there. It was easy to get to the bus and then get to the light rail station.. We visited many parts of the city by bus and light rail. Easy and safe. Love Medellin. Would like to return.
I hear some of the women carry pixie dust and will sprinkle it on you, making you their slave for the moment..

column2: “Medellin- A City not to be missed”
column3: There is no one defining factor that makes Medellin special, it is the mixture of many small things that you may not be able to put your finger on, but will lead to you wanting to stay longer and longer.Called the city of eternal spring, Medellin lives up to its name with incredible spring weather all year round. The city its self is nestled in a valley with its buildings sprawling up the steep sides requiring cable cars for some of the inhabitants to get to and from the centre of town. By night the whole valley lights up making an incredible night time vista.Apart from the natural beauty of the city it is Colombia’s hub for fashion, partying and arguably is home to the most beautiful women on the planet. Furthermore as the city that was once the seat of Pablo Escobar cocaine empire and only two decades ago was the most dangerous city on the planet. It is now a pinup for hope with some of the happiest and friendliest locals who demonstrate that all dark times can be turned around.The Day trip to nearby Guatape is a must when in the area.

Medellin is for me the most beautiful city in colombia, its very modern and has great public transport. ive been a few times and never felt in danger there are great restaurants and lots of activities for old and young!

this town used to be the Colombian mafia hub in the 1990s, the most violent town of Colombia. now is the most developed. its metrocable, metro and cyclist roads, makes it a very attractive city to visit.

The people are generally nice until they get behind the wheel of a vehicle. The city has a lot of traffic that moves fast, so you better keep up with the vibe. The food here is below par, the poverty is noticeable, the smell of unregulated fumes from vehicles are prevalent. If you stay in the better neighborhoods (like Poblado) you might enjoy it, but it is not representative of Medellin in general. The taxis are cheap and the drivers have meters, so there is no cheating. The U.S. $ generally goes a long way here.

I just returned from a 5 day trip to Medellin, my first time in 30 years. Wow what a difference and what a town. Before the trip i read a lot of reviews and was a little disappointed that i booked the trip, so what a nice surprise!First it is safe, if you realize that you are in a big city and be careful as you would be in New York! Next the people, Paisa are much nicer then anyone in any European or American state, they are real friendly and helpful. We went from Poblado to El hueco en every where we felt safe. The weather is great it feels like spring and the flowers are beautiful.It is not a place to shop for clothing as most sizes run small, but for the ladies... Ask for the jeans " levanta colla" they exist! This is an butt lift jeans and it works!
I must say Medellin exceeded all my expectations the people were nice i never felt in danger and the food and service in general was very good. Try the cable car and parque lleras at night for fun

column2: “Give the city a chance- it doesn't deserve its reputation”
column3: Medellin is a city on the move, and is nothing like it was during the horrific days of drug violence. Although it has problems, the city is investing in all kinds of interesting transportation, libraries and parks, and its a good base to use for exploring the surrounding countryside. The people are very warm and welcoming, and I never felt unsafe anywhere. Use basic precautions like you would in any big city, but don't believe the bad news- it's way out of date.
An excellent four-hour city tour highlighting all the sights. Take the cable car for an added experience.

Nothing to write home about. The geographic setting in the valley is perhaps the highlight of the city. Forget about all the "dangerous" routine. I doubt that the city has many more sketchy areas then lots of others. El Poblado currently enjoys the "safe" category but frankly since we walked all around the central district, rode the metrocable and rode several bus routes we felt safe the entire time.BTW, bus #313 is a direct shuttle between the North and South bus terminals. You don't have to mess with the metro and then taxis. Cheap, easy and yes safe. Get another low cost (bus fare $1) "see how the locals live" tours.

If you stay in El Poblado you might have a different experience but a reviewer from March 2014 "Vermontman" hit all of the points. After you did the cable cars, visited the aquarium and a couple of other places you will find yourself staying in your hotel wondering if you can cut your trip short.Last night my friend's 15 year old daughter arrived home from school with an empty backpack.Gun toting robbers entered the city transit bus and robbed everybody of their cellphone and cash.Not on my list of places to repeat.

Medellin is a very nice city that has made an incredible comeback. Obviously, the city still has a bit of a global image problem based on the insane violence of the 80s and 90s but that was a long time ago. We were surprised not only at how nice it was (typically in the Poblado district) but how modern the architecture was, how clean it was, etc. The city skyline is very impressive and it has a lot to offer.

Medellin is nice for all ages. Except for the city, you can take tours to several other attractions like a Coffeetour, Mount Guatape or the historical city of Santa Fe. Best time to be in Medellin is Feria de Las Flores (Aug.) and the Lightfestival (Dec.)

been here for many years and now it is a real up and coming place with none of the old mist eke of drugs, they are here as in all places , just not more like before, just mind were you go , as some still promote the old ways ( charlee / bar hotel is one)

Very beautiful but dangerous place - lots of museums, monuments and places to visit. I recommend especially the the mountain railway. From people in Medellin many times we did hear a warning about the scourge of theft. advised not remove phones and cameras on the street and not take along more money than necessary.

Beautiful, clean, and friendly city surrounded by the Andes mountains at 5000ft above sea level. A drivers dream with great windy roads through the mountains from the airport to a gorgeous city below. The woman are extremely beautiful in every direction you turn. Although they were interested in this very tall fair haired Gringo they were very shy and my lack of Spanish didn't help initiate any deep meaningful conversations sorry to say..).. Interestingly the men wanted to laugh, get to know us, and insisted on sharing a drink on more than one occasion not taking no for an answer. I was pleasantly surprised after hearing stories about drug dealers and such that may have jaded my expectations. In Russia many men looked at me like they wanted to kill me so this was wonderful greeting. We had many laughs even though we understood very little on either side of the boisterous conversation. Not many speak English so needless to say I was an interesting specimen to behold and politely observe especially when on the train. One word of English and every head in train car within earshot turned to see where this strange sound came from..).. Police were abundant but informally dressed, very young, male and female, and extremely friendly and approachable. I never felt uneasy or threatened even walking late at night leaving a neighborhood bar. The people know how to enjoy themselves and you see multiple couples out together eating and dancing romantically in the aisle between tables. 50 bars and restaurants all clustered together in El Problado area with people flowing on the streets in good spirits and a zest for life. Feel free to carry your beer from bar to bar without any hassles and with a smiles from the cops. The food is very good and the water quality from the taps is great. If you like shopping the best mall Ive ever seen is located in downtown Medellin. It has a retractable roof and all the best stores imaginable and must have cost 500 million minimum. A very good transportation system using buses, all new duplicate small taxis, and a very efficient above ground train. Also cable cars that take you up to the top of the mountains. Northern part of the city is poorer with many homes built on the side of mountain with few building codes in effect. Regardless people are happy and well taken care of by the obviously wealthy government. I suspect a 50/50 profit deal with exports (wink wink) is used wisely by politicians for the citizens benefit. Keep peace and keep everybody happy and entertained.Millions spent on leisure and entertainment facilities for the citizen to engage with families on their time off. Cultural centers, science centers, music schools with recitals free to public, many sports arenas and water fountain areas for families to frolic. Thousands on the streets at market shopping, eating fresh fruit squeezed on site, eating freshly fried donuts and chicken on every corner. Fruit you wouldn't recognize and the ones you do are better than you've ever had for a fraction of the cost. Fresh fish from pacific and and other amazonian types fish that will amaze you.Beautiful apartments to rent on airbnb.com and I cant find anything negative to say about my trip. I did smell occasional reefers being lit and smoked during my travels at anytime of day but nobody seemed to care and didn't worry about nearby police arresting. Many offed me a toke while smiling and walking by them but of course I worried I might be pounced on and thrown in the pookie..although tempting I must admit.)..Lots of family life, joy of life, and countless miles of walking up and down hills make for a very happy and healthy Medellin population. Many hostels and backpackers from Australia and everywhere else. On the whole prices for nice accommodation was about $150 a night for a two bedroom, two bath luxury apt with hot tub and nice kitchen. you can go less for a one bedroom or studio and spend much less. Will miss the fresh juices, great coffee, pastries, busy markets and overall vitality of the city.We stayed in the more upscale El Probado area but if I ever returned I wouldn't hesitate venturing to the city center area near "cultural center" where its less money and more lively with markets and the cities real people. If there was one complaint it would be that the city is far from water and I enjoy my ocean swims. Maybe Cartagena next which is a dream city of Colombia on the Caribbean side? ...)

We found the people of Medellin to be extremely polite. You should definitely come with some knowledge of Spanish because no one speaks English :) Good thing I studied for all those years!People say it is dangerous here, but I think that with the country's history, the city has made a huge effort to combat those stereotypes. We never felt unsafe walking around at night. Just use your common sense as you would when traveling abroad, don't be an idiot, be respectful of the local culture, and be aware of your surroundings.We had a lovely time here because of the fact that it is so not touristy and felt relatively untouched by Western culture. I would go back to Colombia and visit other cities, such as Bogota. We didn't want a big city feel this time, which is why we picked Medellin. I highly recommend this city if you're looking for something off the beaten path and beautiful.

In the area around the Hotel Diez we found it safe at night. This is a city surrounded my mountains, it is very picturesque and a drive up into the hills is a delight with some great roadside restaurants.
Very impressed by Medellin: friendly people, interesting places to visit, very efficient public transport and great weather! Wish I had been able to stay for longer.

We just visited Medellin for 3 days and we did 2 day trips. One of the trips was about Pablo Escobar. We spoke to his brother Roberto Escobar who lives in one of his houses and visited the family grave. Furthermore we rode the Metrocable and visited the Jardin Botanica and ate local food. The second trip took us to Guatape where we did a boat trip on the lake and strolled in the small village. Afterwards we went to the Peñol and climbed the 740 steps to the top. The view there is worth the climb. Amazingly beautiful.
Liked the people, the place, the ease of the metro and the nightlife!Liked the Escobar tour, Free walking tour, clubs, bars and most of all the Paisa

After three days in Medellin, I am now contemplating how I could relocate to Medellin. It is that awesome. I recommend staying in El Poblado. Transportation is plentiful, food is great, and everything is cheap. The people are extremely polite and I felt safe at all times.The climate is perfect, the views are breathtaking, and there are as many activities to do as in any major U.S. city. I could go on and on. But the most shocking thing about Medellin is how modern it is. There is plenty of wifi, and reliable utilities. The city is designed well and life there is comfortable.I highly recommend Medellin. I recommend that you go as soon as you can, for as long as you can. I took Willi's tour and fell in love with the place.

lots to see and do in Medellin. should never be bored here. very friendly people. the women are absolutely beautiful! it is very 'fashion' orientated though which i dont like. i like to wear shorts and flip flops (casual) and i got stared at a lot because of this.

column2: “Walk and drive at your own risk. Can be ver hazardous to your health”
column3: I Absolutely love Medellin and travel there frequently on business and pleasure. The major problem with Medellin is the municipality failed miserably in organizing the town to protect pedestrians. Drivers including taxis, bus drivers and truck drivers are without mercy and are deadly. You literally take your life into your own hands attempting to walk anywhere in this lawless town of vehicular outlaws who have absolutely no regard for human life. It is perhaps the saddest and most frightening aspect of my trips to this very special city. If you are American and are used to law and order and properly designed crosswalks and laws protecting pedestrians be prepared for the total and exact opposite here in Medellin.A word of extreme caution. NEVER walk around exposing your cell phone. Even while riding in a taxi. They are worth big bucks and are the biggest item on the list for thieves to steal and they'll think nothing of sticking a knife in your belly to get the phone.Medellin in a great down but not for the faint of heart or the squeamish. Be on guard constantly on this place it is not safe.
I wish I can retire today so I can move there. Love everything about Medellin, the people, the culture, food, the energy, everything about it is great...

This being my sixth time to the City of Eternal Spring, I can honestly say this is where I want to spend the rest of my life. The local Paisa has to be one of the proudest people on Earth and they will go out of their way to help you and show you just how beautiful their city is. I could've stayed anywhere in the city but I chose to stay in Manrique Oriental, one of the more dangerous neighborhoods back in the 90s. It's really hard to pinpoint just one thing about Medellin that stands out. The weather here is by far the most comfortable weather I've experienced. Being from NYC you know just how erratic the weather can be. Not here, it barely gets cooler than 70 degrees Fahrenheit and rarely is it hotter than 90 degrees. The women here are very beautiful and have something about them that draws you closer with every word they speak. The food here is great and for the price its definitely a steal compared to prices back home. I was here in December and booked my flight for Feria de la Flores 2014. I couldn't get enough of this wonderful city that has transformed itself from the murder capital to the most innovative city in the world. I love everything about it. There is beauty all around you. From the birds chirping in the morning to lush green hills of the Aburra Valley that surround Antioquia. Paisas are always partying and their contagious energy is one of the reasons I'm considering moving here for good. Anyone who has thought about visiting Medellin, do so and soon before the secret gets out that this is the best city with the best people in the World. No other place will give you the Quality of Life for the Cost of Living. No city can match. I love Medellin!

Just some notes for my fellow American travelersMedellin is built on the side of a Mountain - unless you are in the valley, everything is walking a hill. Plan on getting taxi for anything more than a couple blocks, unless you're up for some exercise. Taxi is cheap, normally $5-10 just about anywhereEasy Taxi ap is great (Android or iPhone) - you don't just want to hop in a taxi - better to call one with this ap. There have been some tourists that get in troubleNot a lot of tourists here, so it's very helpful if you learn some Spanish. Checkout Pimsleaur's MP3 - in 30 lessons (30 minutes each), you'll know enough to be functional. I bought the class for $99People are friendly - plenty of malls and good restaurants - If you are single, the women are beautiful and love AmericansSomething you may not expect - the average Paisan (person from Medellin) is more polite and better kept than the average American. Some of our countrymen have given us the reputation of rude and unclean. Couple tips - no sneakers or gym shorts unless you are going to the gym. Fashion is big here - dress to impress. Be nice - this is their country. Don't be a jerk - most of these people work hard for about $400/month. The cool thing - Piasans are some of the happiest people in the worldSafest to stay in Pablado (Gringoland) - like any big city, even in America- don't go into bad areas alone at night - you are asking for trouble.The Airport is 30/40 minute ride. Taxi will cost about $35 each way - it's on the other side of the mountain. Great views of the city on the way in and outTemperature is perfect - they call it the Valley of Eternal Spring. Most nights around 55, days mid 70's - all year long. Not too hot, not too coldHope this helps - Les

Great city with lots of interesting art and parks. It's also easy to get away from the city with a day trip to Arvi Park which is easy to get to on the Metro Cable. Real City Tours is a great way to learn about the region from a local. People are very friendly and happy to see tourists enjoying their city which has transformed into a vibrant modern place.

I like to explore new places but in Medellin you are better off with a local guide. The city is big, full of cars and motorcycles and traffic is tremendous. If you don't know where you are going, you end up walking around aimlessly and not getting very far. The Turibus was not worth it.

This should be a must see city on every traveler's list. Medellin is in a mountain valley and extends up the mountainsides in all directions. With a low point at 1500 meters, it is never hot; and because it is 6 degrees north of the equator, it is never cold. The city has art, history, shopping, nightlife and a warm population - well worth a visit. You will enjoy it.

This is one of my favorite cities. Firstly, the temperature throughout the year is just right, it deserves the name the City of Eternal Spring. I try to sample local food when I visit and ate at food outlets frequented by Colombians; I think, though, fish lovers will be a little disappointed. Bagre seems to be the fish that’s most available, I enjoyed it but there is better. Medellin has an excellent transportation system, moving from one part of the city to the other was a breeze. What I liked most about the city was the people, they are very friendly and helpful. I must remark on my visit to the Museo de la Universidad de Antioquia; upon entering I was appointed one of the English speaking guides. This young lady was such a wonderful guide. She spent three hours with me explaining every display in the museum, she was so enthusiastic and helpful. It made me wonder whether such a free tour was available in any other country. I have visited many museums throughout the world and have never before been accorded this facility. I did make a purchase from the Museum Shop. Medellin overall is a very pleasant city.

10 years ago I would not have dreamed of coming to this city. I believe it was the murder capital of the world at one time..How things change..The turn around is simply unbelievable..I stayed in Poblado, an area choke a bloke with great bars, restaurants & high end clothing.The Colombian people are just about the friendliest, warmest people in South America..I cant wait to visit this magical city again

column2: “One of the best cities in South America”
column3: Medellin is well-organized city with lots of culture and everything is covered in green plants. The public transportation is a model for cities all over the world. I have never been in a nicer subway. The people are very friendly in Antioquia. I found it totally amazing that there is no place you look that does not have something growing there. Mango and avocado trees just grow in the medians between streets. The city has well-organized tourist attractions that celebrate the art and culture of Colombia. I went during the 2014 World Cup and it was amazing to see the entire city cheer for their team.

I just return from medellin colombia 2 days ago and I must say that I was blown away when I got there. I was surprise on how clean the downtown area was, not only that but I was really impressed on how good the restaurant was from one name creeps & waffles and one restaurant name 360 which is downtown medellin. So if you go just be safe and just enjoy yourself

While shopping in 3 different malls I was astonished at their beauty by comparison to what I'm used to in the states. I felt like I was from a third world country, they were all very large & beautifully built, demonstrating their construction skills & their extraordinarily creative architects & designers. In each case, marble, granite, as well as natural stone & tiles were used in very artistic manners throughout each mall. The Sante Fe Mall was 5 stories high with an amazing atrium open to the sky yet protected from the daily rains by a huge covering that was supported in such a manner that allowed a free flow of air between it & the building. I've never seen anything quite like this. The many upscale shops, banks, restaurants, ATMs, & thoroughly clean beautiful public restrooms were all very attractive as well as very modern. Certainly the malls that I visited in this city of 4 million people are typical of beautiful city of Medelling which is known as The City of Eternal Spring.

Lovely city centre, vibrant.The metro is very safe with police at every station and on trains also.Our favourite bar is Salon Malaga, next to San Antonio metro station. They play traditional Colombian music here and Saturday nights they have tango dancing
If you are planning to go to Colombia, you have to go to Medellin. Lots of places, museums, parks, malls, beautiful people and countless restaurants.

Safe now, nice climate rains as it gets too hot, its like a paradise. It was built 100s of years ago by a Jewish merchant community, has many rolling mountains that the streets climb. Don't miss out on the amazing malls. Great place to visit.
LandVenture Travel took us to see all the sites and to shopping expedition. Do visit all the towns you can to get the true impression of Antioquia

Loved Medellin! The weather was amazinggg!!! San Diego shopping mall was great, you find anything and everything there!

SO MUCH SAFER THAN THE STORIES YOU'VE HEARD. Colombia as a whole has some of the happiest friendliest people in the world, and Medellin is the Country's favorite city. A beautiful city with wonderful parks, tree lined neighborhoods, restaurants and cafes every couple of hundred feet. 5 star restaurants. high in stores your used to seeing in NYC or L.A. perfect spring weather all year round. You have to visit. THE ONLY RISK IS NOT WANTING TO LEAVE.

These are funny names to most people. The first one sounds funny and for those who know enough Spanish to understand that “playa” means beach, the enormous distance from a beach in Medellin makes it kind of ridiculous as well.I first joked with my wife about the name Carabobo meaning “clown (bobo) face (cara),” but after studying Colombian history I discovered where the name really came from. After Bolivar et.al. won independence for New Granada, later called Gran Colombia (Colombia, Ecuador, Venezuela), removing the Spanish from Colombia and Venezuela became another matter altogether. I mentioned earlier that, Jose Maria Cordoba had been assigned to the task of removing the Spanish from Antioquia and later from Cartagena. When he did so, the Spanish retreated to a small strip of land at the very Northern tip of Colombia called Riohaca and working toward reuniting with their forces in Maracaibo and Caracas. The Battle of Carabobo prevented their reuniting and spelled the end of Spanish occupation in Gran Colombia. Venezuelans still celebrate the Battle of Carabobo on June 24th.Although navigating along the Carabobo can be tricky when it is crowded, it hardly resembles the battlefield that it is named after. Carabobo is a several block closure of a street running North and South a few block adjacent to the Metro tracks. In essence it is a foot-traffic only shopping street. The main shopping is between Parque de Las Luces (Park of Lights), on the southern end and continues to Parque Botero at the northern end (approximately 8 blocks).Pretty much anything that you would like to buy (including some nasty streetwalkers around the church as you are entering into Parque Botero), can be found along the Carabobo. Parque Botero is named for the famous sculpter whose statues (very rotund figures) are throughout the plaza. The museum of Antioquia is located in Parque Botero, as well as Palacio de la Cultura (cultural palace). In spite of the ugly distraction around the church, the area offers a uniquely Paisa experience.If you continue east a couple of blocks on Calle 52 (52nd Street), right in front of the Palacio de la Cultura, you will wind up in another several blocks of streets that are for foot traffic only. This is known as La Playa. Though it isn’t as long as Carabobo, it is still an excellent, uniquely Paisa shopping experience that you might enjoy.Though I have been in these areas alone and also with Sandra, I do not advise gringos to be in those areas after dark and don’t go wandering too far off of the beaten path alone. Being a rather adventurous and independent sort, I have done so one time, taking a shortcut back to the Metro on the northern end and found myself in a very seedy area that gave me the willies. I passed through the area without incident, but I stayed at a brisk pace, had my head up and watching my surroundings and I’m 6’3 and 230 lbs and it was broad daylight.Bil Howard is the author of "Chulos, Chuzos and Hotdog Condoms: Surviving as a Gringo in Medellin, Colombia," for more information http://bilhoward.blogspot.com

A stunning city with leafy neighborhoods, cafes, boutiques, hotels and much more! world class museums and fantastic food in the many fantastic restaurants. The new metro is one of the world's finest and very inexpensive. It includes cable cars that go up out of the city. The weather is absolutely perfect - not too hot or cold and you can leave your windows open 24/7 because there are really no bugs to intrude! But the best thing about Medellin is the people! They are genuinely warm, friendly and helpful. During our two month stay there, we never felt unsafe - riding in taxis, walking, etc. Highly recommended!
The people and culture are lovely and are patient if your Spanish isn't that great. I can't wait to return

column2: “Put it on the top ten list”
column3: Great city, lots of things to view, do with a different prospective than the rest of Colombia. It's San Francisco South American style from great neighborhoods suburds like Parque Poblado, Parque Lerras to my favorite Laureles

column2: “Great City to Visit; a city of eternal spring”
column3: Medellin is a beautiful city to visit in the Andes Mountains of Columbia. The people are lovely, the weather is great, and the food is good. The atmosphere is very relaxed, and there are many things to do, including the museum with the Botero exhibition.
Charming city with a lot of history, which you definitely should take your time learning about. Good nightlife, nice people!
Not much to dislike, many things to see and do. Excellent Metro and be sure to ride the cable cars to the top of the mountain. Do not forget the walking tour.

The best thing we did was the walking tour through the famed dangerous parts but the walking guide was fantastic he was arranged through our hostel @ the Black Sheep. He gave the history and stories about the changing City & the impacts that the drug cartels had on the people & the city. It was not the Pablo Escobar Tour it was way better. He took us into the parts of the city that people are afraid to go but he was entertaining and very informative we did not feel at risk. This is a wonderful city the people are fantastic...in fact I absolutely loved Colombia and will return in 2015

column2: “We fell in LOVE with the city”
column3: Medellin is a city that have 3 trees for every one citizen and what you will find is a lush, tropicla city with a fantstic follage and lush gardens and trees. The people and restaurants are also pleasant with impecable service. Not to miss are the Museo de Antioquia, Plaza Botero, Pies Descalsos Park, Parque Nutibara, Parque Lleras, El Peñol de Guatape. We look forward to our visting Medellin again and again
The pearl of ANdes. Lovely terrain, landscapes and night views. Fantastic food, warm and inclusive community. Spend more than 3 nights if you can :)

column2: “No longer the city of eternal spring. Now its Summer.”
column3: Every day was hot, and fhe traffic is unbearable and this once quiet little town is now a sprawling metropolis rivaling New York and L.A. the air quality for the most part is very poor due to geography and poor emmission controls. i Looove this place honestly and truly no matter how unhealthy and nutty this place is. It has soul and flavor and life. It throbs with emotion. And the food is awesome.

Forget everything that you think you may know about Medellin or Colombia. It is one of the most impressive places I've been and I've travelled to 6 continents. It's beautiful, organized, clean, going green. You simply need to go to understand how lovely it is. Open air museum of Botero sculptures, a botanical garden that takes your breath away, the trip from the airport is worth the price of the ticket to Medellin. The Metro and the Metro cable. And the people: beautiful, friendly, helpful. Breathtaking scenery. There's a great NY Times review from Jan.2013 that will tell you how this city has changed . Voted the most innovative city on the world for 2013, competing against Dubai, NYC, Rio; that should give you a big clue as to how great this city is.

A must visit.. so much to do there.. I recommend eating a Dona Rosa a few minutes from the airport, then visiting Rio Negro, El Penol, Pueblito Paisa, La Plaza Botero (look up Painter Fernando Botero)... fun city.. modern infrastructure.. everything from drinks (particular AGUA ARDIENTE) to transportation, clothing is very affordable..Enjoy Latin America!

column2: “A busy, noisy city but with much to see in and around”
column3: This is a city! Ok so you have to expect many people, sometimes noisy people, and they love to party, and have fun. People also want to drive and with no national railway system there is a lot on the roads,and sadly pollution is very evident, although not admitted by the locals.This is a city of "haves" and "have nots". There are many who have made it and live in one of the many newly developed high rise apartments, and there are plenty who live in slums, broken down buildings and even tents by the river. Driving around can be a challenge, or nightmare as some would see it.Take time to dig beneath this, there are many interesting places to visit and unusual items to see; The Museum of Antioquia is a must with the Botero statues and paintings, The Museum El Castillo, built in 1930 in medieval Gothic style, the Uribe Palace of culture, the metro and metro cable cars are great ways to get around.Then there is so much in the surrounding areas, Santa Fe de Antioquia, El Panol de Guatape, Rio Claro and so on. The climate is also very acceptable, with day time temperatures in the 20s much of the time.An interesting city - visit it and it's surroundings if you can.

I recommend visiting in Colombia. It is modern, clean, has great "democratic" architecture, and friendly people. We never felt unsafe and had a very good experience with the great metro system. We spent too much time in Bogota which is jammed with traffic instead of in the much more pleasant Medellin. Great airport as well with inexpensive bus option to downtown or San Diego mall..taxis very expensive from airport unless you share one for about 13000 per person

Medellin has lost its bad reputation of years ago. It is now a safe and modern city with great mass transportation. Very affordable taxi service should be avoided during the rush hours which includes the lunch time. Take a trip to Santa Fe de Antioquia - an antique town from 1524 and a capital of the region before Medellin.
We didn't love Medellin as much as everyone else seems to have - it's incredibly polluted such that you can taste and smell it. Stick to the coffee areas.

Medellín is known as the ciudad de la eterna primavera (city of eternal spring) because of its very consistant climate throughout the year. The city is a top travel destination thanks to its infrastructure, its climate, social and urban transformation, cultural life and the combination of traditional and modern architecture. The neighborhood of El Poblado is the perfect place to enjoy the nightlife.experiencescolombia

We're overlanding across South America, driving through another big city is an experience in itself. The city is crowded, polluted and highly congested… Unless you need the chaos, head for the hills!!! Hope this review was helpful!!!

If you are not in Colombia to 'party' or partake in some of its infamous produce give this city a wide berth. It is an immensely shallow place where the label ‘Punta Gringo’ is worn with pride. Armani move over.
great city to chill out and also to make party. Medellin I love you. the people are friendly and you can really feeling at home.

column2: “Sorry but I just don't get this place.”
column3: After reading reviews where everyone says that you must see Medellin, I had to see Medellin. I've been elsewhere in Colombia and like the country very much. But I don't get this city. It's a pretty standard mid sized Latin American city with not much to recommend it. Maybe I've seen a few too many, but this is kind of like someone coming to the United States for the first time and visiting say, Kansas City or Indianapolis. Ok towns, but what am I doing here? Sorry I can't get on the bandwagon. I speak Spanish. If you don't, you will either meet young college kids who do or wind up not meeting anyone. Clean? I didn't find it that way once I left El Poblado and environs. Anywhere a tourist might wish to visit has lots of hawkers I've done the third world and I hate hawkers. I think lots of travelers give places rave reviews because, well, they don't want to admit to themselves they blew a week somewhere they really don't want to revisit. So Medellin, while I like the brickwork and tile roofs and for some reason met the absolutely funniest and most entertaining cab drivers when I was there, I made the mistake of leaving the tourist path and wandering into the rest of the city with its pollution, miles of bad car repair places, and I've seen that before. Make your own decision. I always have fun and had fun there. But if I only had a couple of weeks of vacation, I'd pick somewhere else.

column2: “An Incredible City With a Lot to Offer”
column3: At the time of writing this review, I have spent nearly a month in Medellin and this is my second trip. First, No one should be afraid to travel here. Yes, it has a history which may scare you, but it is just that...history. Scratch the surface and you find an incredible place with welcoming people, great infrastructure, clean water, more salsa than you can handle, and an overall incredible spot.There is also a large diversity of areas to visit. While most travelers are drawn to the rich area El Poblado, it is a somewhat false image of the city itself. I strongly recommend spending your time OUTSIDE of Poblado! Anyways, check out the university areas, downtown (San Antonio), Calle 70 (Laureles), and Calle 33.

Medellin used to be out of bounds to foreigners because of Pablo Escobar and it fame as a major centre fro the drug trade. Shootings occurred every day. However, this is now mainly history. Like any major City one has to be street-wise and Medellin still has its problems. However, our group of 7 spent two days there and never felt threatened. We toured the parks, visited museums and had a great time. My recommendation? Spend 3-4 days there. There is lots to see.

Spent three days here with spouse. Weather is perfect! People are very nice. Easy to get around city using Metro ($1,800 per ticket) and cabs are safe and affordable. Some nice museums and also some good restaurants in the Poblado area. Use common sense and be aware of your surroundings. Don't want to stick out like a Western tourist? Leave the shorts and flip flops in your hotel/hostel. You stick out and look dumb as no locals wear shorts or flip flops.Give Medellin a try-I think you'll be surprised. We really enjoyed our long weekend there.

This city has it ALL. Tattooed hipsters serving excellent coffee? Check (Pergamino). Amazing local designers selling their wares at very reasonable prices? Check (Poblado and Laureles). Beautiful historic districts free of tourists? Check (Prado). Great museums, colonial cathedrals and stunning public art? Check (check out Real City Tours walking tour of the city - exceptional). Peaceful, fresh, open green spaces with hiking tracks, horse rides and lakes? Check (Parque Arvi). World class Olympic stadium with one of the best aquatic complexes I have ever come across - with apnea training! - and great gym facilities? Check (Estadio complex). Cleanest and safest public transport in the world, with cable cars? Check (ride the metro system day or night, we certainly have). Welcoming and friendly locals eager to share their city? Check - and in abundance. Medellin has been the biggest surprise of our Latin American adventure. I could live here tomorrow. Love, love, love!

column2: “Nice, but don't go out of your way”
column3: Medellin is a very large city. I think the beauty of visiting Colombia is its villages. But if you are coming this way anyway, it is worth a visit.
Yea... Walk around in the woods or go to the ecological park. If you have a girl, take her to the butterfly house, otherwise I would skip this place

column2: “A great city to visit and explore”
column3: This city was a pleasant surprise for us, and was a much better experience than we anticipated. It is beautiful,very clean,and has menu interesting sites to visit. However, the best experience was the friendly,helpful,happy people of Medellin.

column2: “Wonderful City. Plenty to see, good transport systems”
column3: We only stayed for 5 days and I wish we had stayed for longer, There is so much to see. The Antioquena folk are friendly, helpful and rightly proud of their capital city. I was very impressed with the transport systems. I am a "Third Age" person and I was immediately offered a seat on the metro by an attractive young lady! Also impressed by the shopping malls. I recommend the turibus. It's a great way to get a feel for the City. If you are visiting Colombia don't miss Medellin.
Kind people, beautiful women, and clean, organised and tourist-friendly city. Parque Lleras is a great place for drinks and nightlife.
One of the greatest and modern cities in the world. The USA govt don't want you to know, very safe in Pablado great time
you can see why so many people love this place. it is in a beautiful valley, friendly people, and the feel of the new Colombia. Great music too

We really enjoyed our few days in Medellin over Christmas--lots of great restaurants; an exhilarating, throbbing market downtown on Christmas Eve; and the Christmas lights are impressive with a festival atmosphere.

Medellin is the heart of Antioquia. A home for fashion, arts, and modern development. Nestled in a mountain range Medellin has diverse landscapes and scenic views. The climate is very comfortable with light clothing but you may want to dress a little warmer if you head for higher elevations. The metro train is the pride of public transportation in Medellin and the Metro Cable is worth taking all the way up. Of course the various light displays in December are amazing as well. Medellin has a very nice zoo, a large national park, and points of interest such as el pueblito paisa and the art work of Fernando Botero. Be advised that Medellin is a very crowded city and has the problems of most major cities. Traffic is terrible during the day and if you can I recommend avoiding public buses. With a little planning and patience however, you can enjoy one of Colombia's must see places.

column2: “Postcard from Colombia: City of Eternal Spring”
column3: Just days into my family’s annual vacation in Colombia, I have seen butterflies with wings transparent as glass. Thousands of candles floating in the air above a rushing river, flanked by lit-up fairy tale homes. A park full of giant fat people, sculpted in bronze, in a city better known for beautiful slender women.Posting to you live from Medellin, the City of Eternal Spring, I can confirm that toilets do not in fact flush in the opposite direction south of the equator. But I’ve found the sort of spectacles I hoped for when I handed over the keys last week to friends housesitting our upstate New York home, and flew 3,000 miles south with my twelve-year old daughter and Colombian wife. Though we’ve visited my wife’s home country more than a dozen times, each visit we sift for something new, opening ourselves up to places and people we’d otherwise miss.So far, this trip has not disappointed. After landing in Bogota last Wednesday, we flew, along with five members of my wife’s family, to Medellin, Colombia’s second-largest city, known for its year-round spring-like climate. In a van on the winding road from the airport, we passed farms rising on green folds of land, ramshackle huts peddling everything from fruits to doghouses. Suddenly the city appeared in a valley, stuck between cloud-swaddled mountains, tall sleek buildings vying for attention with orange tiled roofs. It was morning; we’d been traveling by plane and vehicles since 4:30 a.m. We stopped at a mirador, or overlook, to check out the city below.We settled in at the Medellin house of friends where we’re staying — our wonderful hosts Dario and Georgina Arango. The next day, we went downtown to check out a park filled with 23 bronze sculptures of fat characters created by Botero, the renowned Colombian artist and native of Medellin. The idea behind the permanent display was to rejuvenate the downtown, but there’s few signs of rebirth beyond the sculptures. The area is packed with unsavory characters, traffic, and thousands of small vendors selling everything from imported shoes to incense to drugs. We kept a sharp eye on our kids and wallets. Nevertheless, we enjoyed taking photos alongside the sculptures.On Sunday, we traveled on the Medellin Metro, Colombia’s only subway system, which in fact only travels above ground. Sometimes way, way above ground. Subway fare of 1,800 pesos, about a buck, includes a stunning ride on cable cars up a mountain crammed with poor neighborhoods known as comunes (in Brazil they’re called favelas). It was from here that Pablo Escobar once hired his henchmen. The eight of us squeezed into a cable car that slowly jerked us diagonally higher, soaring above tin roofs weighted with bricks to keep from blowing off, impossibly steep steps connecting unstable huts, and, implausibly, three cubic glass library buildings jutting out amid this mini-city of poor residences.After a few miles up the mountain on the cable car the comunes gave way to pine forest and we switched to another cable car section that took us to Parque Arvi, a nature preserve spread over hundreds of acres. It includes forest trails, a mariposario, or butterfly house, zip lines, and a small outdoor market of locally grown fruits, vegetables, and typical Colombian foods. It was inside the mariposario where we witnessed one of Colombia’s most striking butterflies – the crystal wing, with wings you can see right through.After returning by cable car back down the mountain, we rested at the house of our kind hosts before returning with them by van that night to witness Medellin’s audacious display of Christmas lights. At 6 p.m. the lights come on around Rio Medellin, where candles suspended above the river glow between rows of illuminated houses. All told, some 27 million Christmas lights spanning 472 miles decorate the city, according to the Medellin public utilities company. According to my daughter, “They’re awesome.”

My husband and I chose to spend Christmas in Medellin mostly due to the incredible light display in the downtown area. Although the lights were indeed fabulous, seeing them was quite an effort. Traffic was bumper to bumper, walking was not advised so the experience was rather disappointing.As for Medellin itself, there are some beautiful areas with lots of greenery to see but there really isn't much to do. Although we got good recommendations on restaurants we found the food rather ordinary. Don't know about the night life as we don't stay out late. Shopping was like any major city. Very little in the area of handcrafts or indigenous art. We stayed a week but three days would have been more than enough time.

This is a very cool city to visit with many nice restaurants and bars and cool people. Be aware of your surroundings and the people you encounter. Most people are just plain friendly and interested in where you're from. But there is still an element that will try to scam you or worse. Don't fall for the plainclothes policemen act.

Medellin day! This means all ladies enter clubs free and drink free all night. Men pay $15USD and drink unlimited until 1a.m.This is not a joke this happens and its amazing. Have the "Ron Medellin" Rum and the white liquor (Ant...)not sure of spelling but the women will be literally fighting over it. Book your trip to have a Thursday in it!!! I mean it!

Great city and people, it has come a long way from the hardship of the Escobar days. The people there are very proud of the way the city and it's people have rose from the ashes to become a first rate city. It's a hidden gem that is still trying to overcome the negative perception first time foreign travels may have of the city.

Very beautiful views, good restaurants and warm people. I felt safe everywhere I've been to. Wheather is always good, between 19 and 30 celsius. You should only get a cab in advance in case a storm is coming, they disapear after start raining.

column2: “Beautiful and Clean city with sweet people.”
column3: I was a visitor from the USA. Medellín is my favorite city in Colombia so far. The city is very clean. I have observed workers scrubbing cement power poles, the metro, and about everything else! It is the cleanest city I have ever visited. The mountain views are great and the climate is temperate. All kinds of social activities are available--restaurants, music, art, dance, etc. You will love this city and won't want to go home. Cautions: Like any city, beware of where you go at night. Stay in safe areas and you will love it.

Medellin is highly recommended as a place for Americans to retire. Why would anyone want to live in city where virtually no one speaks English. Also one would have a drive a car. If one doesn't know Spanish, getting a drivers license would not be possible. Many of the streets aren't hilly, they're mountainous.

I came to visit 3 years ago and decided to stay. I love this place. The Metro is the cleanest I've ever seen, the people are so friendly, the food is traditional and hearty, the city is youthful and happy. I have had so much fun living here. I love this Paisa city. :D
loved this city. the train through the city to the gondolas is amazing. the weather was perfect and people seemed friendly enough. nightlife was good and so was the day time activities.
As a developing city, I found it relatively clean, and the air fresh. Very friendly people. Take the cable car to the park and travel there by the Metro system.
much better than I expected! the metro is good....the restaurants are very nice...yet there are many great architecture around the city

Brilliant loved it. Met some lovely people some of the relatives of the bride (whose wedding we went out for) they made us so welcome and invited us everywhere and wouldnt let us pay for anything in the end we had to insist on paying for something. Lovely city. Metro brilliant and cheap and clean. Exito supermarket brilliant. shops and people and restaurants lovely. so many to choose from. Went to San Antonio with sister of bride who is Colombian and went to market in San Antonio brilliant. had a fab time lovely shops and went to famous coffee shop Astors in San Antonio for coffee, cakes etc - lovely wld go again. Enjoyed it very much

Medellin have two faces the smart nice areas around Poblado. This area can be recommended, try to find a hotel here. There are a lot of nice restaurants in this area. I was unlucky and had to check in in a downtown hotel. Althought Hotel Nutibara was very nice the area around the hotel was not so nice. I don't think there is a problem during the day but one need to be very careful during the evenings. Don't walk on the streets behind the hotel Nutibara there the unlucky people spend their evenings looking for food, drugs and maybe even worse someone to rob. I hade difficulties to find a nice restaurant near Hotel Nutibara! There are no doubts you will see a lot of suffering people in downtown Medellin

I really enjoyed this tour. It's an informative and entertaining insight into arguably Medellin's most notorious historical figure in recent times. The guide does not sugarcoat the devastating influence and legacy that Escobar's cartel left, nor does the guide paint him as a pure villan, which to some of Medellin's most disadvantaged he wasn't. The tour takes you to various sites of significance during Escobar's life and times, including his grave. It ends with a visit to Roberto Escobar's (brother of Pablo and former cartel accountant) current residence. Roberto openly encouraged our questions, photos and was keen to explain his post cartel pursuits in the medical research field in finding a cure for HIV.Like it or not, Pablo Escobar was an influencial historical figure in this incredible city's living memory, who people will continue to find fascinating. There is no sweeping him or the cartel's dirt under the carpet and anyway, when did prohibition ever really work? I hope Medellin recognises that in tourists gaining more insight and knowledge about one aspect of its past, they can also see how far the city has come in healing its brutally violent scars in such a short space of time. This goes to show how resilient and passionate the people of Medellin are in shaping this city now, a lasting legacy that Pablo could only have dreamt of.

There are a lot of misconceptions on the internet about ones' safety in Medellin. I had read many reviews prior to my visit and so had my reservations about visiting. My friend, who lives there, put my mind at ease. I'm glad I took her advice and decided to go. I found Medellin to be a very charming and friendly place. I became seduced by its warmth from the moment I went through customs at Jose Maria Cordova airport about 55 miles from Medellin. Customs agents actually made me feel welcome in their country!
